Def.Name: Balsam Fir
Def.Description: Small to medium sized coniferous tree. Growth occurs in whrols of branches surrounding an upright leader, making a symmetric tree with a broad base and narrow top. 40' - 75' tall with trunk up to 18".
Def.Leaves: Evergreen needles 3/4" - 1" long, flat and often strongly curved. Shiny green with two silvery lines below.
Def.Twigs: Grayish, smooth. Twigs with needles have a generally flattened apperance. Buds, yellowish-brown, blunt, sticky, clustered.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Seed Cones: 2" - 4" long, purplish in color, and stand erect on branches (as do those of all true firs).
Def.Bark: Smooth, thin, and grayish, distinguished by soft blisters containing a clear, odiferous resin known as Canadian balsam.
Def.Range: Distributed throughout the Northeast and upper Midwest. Hardy to Zone 3a.
Def.Remarks: Used primarily for Christmas trees and pulpwood. Because of its thin bark, shallow root system, and flammable needles, balsam fir is easily killed by fire.
